author: jochembrouwer
content:
It is not entirely clear to me if deployment of ORIGIN is disabled in general, or if it is only disabled in EOF contracts.

Also, side question, can EOF contracts call into legacy contracts? Because then you can still retrieve ORIGIN ðŸ¤” And I think also the other way around, legacy -> EOF and there is a "trusted contract" which forwards the ORIGIN as calldata (you can check the sender, if it is the trusted contract then ORIGIN can still enter the EOF stack)

author: fivedogit
content:
Q1: All contracts must be EOF once EOF is enabled, thus this ban will disallow new references to ORIGIN going forward
Q2: Existing ORIGINs will continue to operate as usual, even if referenced from new contracts.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Ahh ok I might not be up to date with the EOF spec, I thought legacy contracts could still be deployed

author: jochembrouwer
content: Makes sense, thanks ðŸ™‚

author: fivedogit
content: Maybe someone else can chime in, but I thought the whole point of EOF was to enforce a universally readable standard from the time EOF goes live. Allowing legacy deployments would defeat that purpose.

author: jochembrouwer
content: I might be on a too old version of EOF ðŸ™‚

author: _shemnon
content: No, EOF and legacy will live together for some time.

author: _shemnon
content: Banning new legacy deployments is possible, but would need some real value.  Certainly not before verkle is deployed in the most wildly optimistic scenario.  5 years out maybe.

author: fivedogit
content: Why does legacy need to still be supported?

author: _shemnon
content: (a) The tooling isn't going to turn on a dime overnight and (b) there are still some things EOF won't do because we are removing.  Smart contract wallets depend on Gas introspection, for example.

author: _shemnon
content: For smart contract wallets what I am holding out for protocol level account abstraction, otherwise we may need to restore some form of gas introspection.

author: fivedogit
content: Is banning ORIGIN in EOF even worthwhile, then, in your opinion?

author: _shemnon
content: I'm neutral on it.

author: fivedogit
content: It still has the effect of discouraging misuse of ORIGIN, even if it doesn't ban outright.

author: fivedogit
content: I'm curious to hear grumblings from devs about "why is ORIGIN gone?" and hear how they've been mucking up their contracts.

author: _shemnon
content: It does send a message, but unless we do dramatic things like make it return SENDER (which has pushback) we son't be able to force change as they can just create a lecacy and call into it to get the value.

author: pdobacz
content:
EOF implementers call notes from today:

Client & EIP Updates:
- https://github.com/ipsilon/eof/blob/main/spec/implementation_matrix.md up-to-date.
- evmone - EIP-7069 merged, making progress on EIP-7620
- besu - making progress on EIP-7620, other complete barring completness of reference tests
- reth - making progress on eof validation
- EIP-7069 updates - merged

Spec discussions:
- EXT*CALL Status codes - postponed
- TXCREATE-less EOF - rejected, TXCREATE has an important use case. Will be noted in EIP-7620's Rationale
- EOF without the irregular state change for the Creator Contract - there will be a PR to Megaspec to demonstrate the alternative spec, discussion to continue next week
- Dissallowing empty initcodes array or 0-byte initcode - accepted, will be applied
- Ban ORIGIN - postponed
- Validating initcode vs runtime containers based on how they're referenced and/or whether they have RETURNCONTRACT or not - rejected, seems like the merit (blocking unknown abuses) doesn't warrant the extra complexity to validation. Will be noted in EIP-7620's Rationale section
